title: Environmental Information Request – Street Lighting Classification for Footways & Cycleways

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Under the Environmental Information Regulations 2004 (EIR), I am requesting information on the lighting classification applied to footways and cycleways in your administrative area.
Could you please provide:
1) The lighting classes (eg P1, P2, P3, C4, etc.) used for footways within your administrative area, specifying if these differ for:
- Primary footways (high-footfall areas such as city centres, high streets, or transport hubs).
- Secondary footways (medium footfall, e.g. residential and suburban streets).
- Tertiary footways (low footfall areas such as cul-de-sacs, alleyways, or rural paths).
2) The lighting class used for cycleways, particularly where they are:
- Dedicated cycleways (physically separated from roads and footways).
- Shared footway/cycleway routes.
3) If different lighting classes are applied depending on location (urban vs rural), please provide a breakdown.
4) Any internal policies, guidance, or strategy documents that define or inform how lighting classes are selected for footways and cycleways.
I would appreciate confirmation of receipt of this request.
Best wishes
Guy Mayhew

Dear Guy Mayhew,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Street Lighting
Classification for Footways & Cycleways which we received on 11/02/2025.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
1) The lighting classes (e.g. P1, P2, P3, C4, etc.) used for footways
within your administrative area, specifying if these differ for:
- Primary footways (high-footfall areas such as city centres, high
streets, or transport hubs).
Footpaths in these areas were either included in the C class calculation
appropriate for the area (city centre / high streets etc) or were covered
by the surround ratio aspect of the chosen M class (traffic routes M2, M3
or M4) in our 2012 – 2017 CIP design to BS5489.
- Secondary footways (medium footfall, e.g. residential and suburban
streets).
These were included in the relevant P class designated to the street (P3,
P4 or P5 depending on road class). The calculations included from rear of
footpath to rear of footpath in our 2012 – 2017 CIP design to BS5489.
- Tertiary footways (low footfall areas such as cul-de-sacs, alleyways, or
rural paths).
Cul de-sacs were included in the relevant P class designated to the street
(P4 or P5 depending on road class). The calculations included from rear of
footpath to rear of footpath. Alleyways and rural paths were lit to P5/P6
but only if they previously had a system of road lighting. Previously
unlit footpaths remained unlit in our 2012 – 2017 CIP design to BS5489.
2) The lighting class used for cycleways, particularly where they are:
- Dedicated cycleways (physically separated from roads and footways).
Dedicated routes were treated the same as alleyways / rural footpaths in
our 2012 – 2017 CIP design to BS5489
- Shared footway/cycleway routes.
If adjacent to a road, then these were covered by the surround ratio
aspect of the chosen M class (traffic routes M2, M3 or M4. Dedicated
routes were treated the same as alleyways / rural footpaths in our 2012 –
2017 CIP design to BS5489
3) If different lighting classes are applied depending on location (urban
vs rural), please provide a breakdown:
All remote footpaths being treated the same, wherever the location.
Footways adjacent to carriageways were included in the chosen class for
the road which would differ between rural and urban in our 2012 – 2017 CIP
design to BS5489
4) Any internal policies, guidance, or strategy documents that define or
inform how lighting classes are selected for footways and cycleways:
This is determined by the lighting class assigned by Sheffield City
Council to the relevant street. Designs are in accordance with the current
BS5489 and any relevant ‘Institute of Lighting Professionals’ guidance
documents.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see

https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
